00008 #ifndef __HASHTABLE_CWC22_H__
00009 #define __HASHTABLE_CWC22_H__
00010 
00011 #include "hashtable_private.h"
00012 
00013 /* Example of use:
00014  *
00015  *      struct hashtable  *h;
00016  *      struct some_key   *k;
00017  *      struct some_value *v;
00018  *
00019  *      static unsigned int         hash_from_key_fn( void *k );
00020  *      static int                  keys_equal_fn ( void *key1, void *key2 );
00021  *
00022  *      h = create_hashtable(16, hash_from_key_fn, keys_equal_fn);
00023  *      k = (struct some_key *)     malloc(sizeof(struct some_key));
00024  *      v = (struct some_value *)   malloc(sizeof(struct some_value));
00025  *
00026  *      (initialise k and v to suitable values)
00027  * 
00028  *      if (! hashtable_insert(h,k,v) )
00029  *      {     exit(-1);               }
00030  *
00031  *      if (NULL == (found = hashtable_search(h,k) ))
00032  *      {    printf("not found!");                  }
00033  *
00034  *      if (NULL == (found = hashtable_remove(h,k) ))
00035  *      {    printf("Not found\n");                 }
00036  *
00037  */
00038 
00039 /* Macros may be used to define type-safe(r) hashtable access functions, with
00040  * methods specialized to take known key and value types as parameters.
00041  * 
00042  * Example:
00043  *
00044  * Insert this at the start of your file:
00045  *
00046  * DEFINE_HASHTABLE_INSERT(insert_some, struct some_key, struct some_value);
00047  * DEFINE_HASHTABLE_SEARCH(search_some, struct some_key, struct some_value);
00048  * DEFINE_HASHTABLE_REMOVE(remove_some, struct some_key, struct some_value);
00049  *
00050  * This defines the functions 'insert_some', 'search_some' and 'remove_some'.
00051  * These operate just like hashtable_insert etc., with the same parameters,
00052  * but their function signatures have 'struct some_key *' rather than
00053  * 'void *', and hence can generate compile time errors if your program is
00054  * supplying incorrect data as a key (and similarly for value).
00055  *
00056  * Note that the hash and key equality functions passed to create_hashtable
00057  * still take 'void *' parameters instead of 'some key *'. This shouldn't be
00058  * a difficult issue as they're only defined and passed once, and the other
00059  * functions will ensure that only valid keys are supplied to them.
00060  *
00061  * The cost for this checking is increased code size and runtime overhead
00062  * - if performance is important, it may be worth switching back to the
00063  * unsafe methods once your program has been debugged with the safe methods.
00064  * This just requires switching to some simple alternative defines - eg:
00065  * #define insert_some hashtable_insert
00066  *
00067  */
00068 
00077 struct hashtable *
00078 create_hashtable(unsigned int minsize,
00079                  unsigned int (*hashfunction) (void*),
00080                  int (*key_eq_fn) (void*,void*),
00081                  void (*vff)(void*));
00082 
00099 int 
00100 hashtable_insert(struct hashtable *h, void *k, void *v);
00101 
00108 void *
00109 hashtable_search(struct hashtable *h, void *k);
00110 
00117 void * /* returns value */
00118 hashtable_remove(struct hashtable *h, void *k);
00119

00125 unsigned int
00126 hashtable_count(struct hashtable *h);

00134 void
00135 hashtable_destroy(struct hashtable *h, int free_values);
